channel.name: My zkApp takes 8min to compile on the browser. Any ways to reduce this time?

messages.content:
My zkApp takes 8min to compile on the browser. Any ways to reduce this time?
It has just three simple functions. 2 to append to action states and 1 to reduce the action state.
this is expected AFAIU
but there's compilation caching now/on the way
Ok. Any tickets that I can track? Or any ETA for that?
Also, I'm trying to submit a project for mina navigators.. so if I don't have a UI, how will I be able to submit the project.
it's been already released https://github.com/o1-labs/o1js/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md#changed-1

embeds.title: o1js/CHANGELOG.md at main · o1-labs/o1js
embeds.description: TypeScript framework for zk-SNARKs and zkApps. Contribute to o1-labs/o1js development by creating an account on GitHub.

messages.content: I think this only applies to nodejs.. I'm compiling on the browser.
the same principle should work
yeah it doesn't seem to have anything node specific apart from filesystem, so if you ship the compiled keys to the client and pass custom cache object it could work
@Faserisko Can you give an example please. Something like a code snippet?
The example in the linked PR#1187 (https://github.dev/o1-labs/o1js/pull/1187/files) does not have any example of this
Found something related to this.. will try it out. Thanks!

You need to implement a cache object with the read function that will return the corresponding key based on the header
https://github.com/o1-labs/o1js/blob/main/src/lib/proof-system/cache.ts#L165-L182

I haven't tried it myself so I don't have any snippet and I'm not sure if it will actually work.

embeds.title: o1js/src/lib/proof-system/cache.ts at main · o1-labs/o1js
embeds.description: TypeScript framework for zk-SNARKs and zkApps. Contribute to o1-labs/o1js development by creating an account on GitHub.

messages.content: For node, it works in this way: https://discord.com/channels/484437221055922177/1168969852296376461/1168982953699848343

Hey, i'm also having issues compiling in browser. My contract doesn't compile at all whereas it is done with node in 30 sec. It is just running forever...
So if you have some solution using a cache I would be interested.

Looks like a memory issue. Can you try to increase the memory available to compile() in the browser? 

Also, see this post about using pre-compiled verification keys only (not sure that can be done now on the web, but it will be possible in future I believe): https://discord.com/channels/484437221055922177/1168969852296376461/1169580485312249876

It got really interesting very quickly.. the cache directory is 1.2GB 😅 
Now just deciding whether to download this file on users machine or compile it.. or make it a race condition 🤦‍♂️
Mostly the prover keys are taking space.. 400MB for each method in the zkApp

Found an interesting thing that.. if I remove all the PKs from the cache, the zkApp still compiles under 40s (which was taking 5mins)
And the keys are then compiled when I try to create a proof.
I'll try to go ahead with loading all non `pk` cache files in the browser before starting compilation.. then in the background download pk cache files.
Lets see how that goes
If you verify the proof of ZkProgram in your SmartContract, you don't need pk, only vk, and can skip generating or downloading pk. If you generate the proof, then you need pk.
Thanks for the info
Not doing that at the moment
But that was the plan for later
But I need to create proofs from the ZkProgram in the webapp
So I'll have to compile the zkProgram anyway
And AFAIK, ZkProgram does not support caching at the moment
Upgrade to o1js 0.14.1 to get caching in a custom folder for ZkProgram. You can also consider sending proof generation job to serverless backend
But then it defeats the purpose of ZK.. right?
I’ll try the caching approach for ZK program

Not necessary. You can have proof that
1) Do not have confidential inputs
2) You protect confidential inputs by some method like hashing
3) you split proof into 2 proofs - one handling confidential data on the user's computer and the other handling CPU-intensive proof with non-confidential inputs
Cool
I'll try that out
Please let me know if you will succeed with caching in the web environment; I haven't tried it yet
Sure

@DFST I was able to get the caching to work on browser as well.. Now the compilation time is 40s on browser as well. Thanks for all the help.
Next I'll try to send a transaction to check if everything is working as expected.

congrats! How did you do it? I had to give up on this for now. But maybe I get it working tomorrow. So you basically compile the zkProgram with node and load the pk an vk in the browser? You got some code for me to understand that?

For me the files were:
```
const files = [
  { name:'srs-fp-65536', type: 'string' },
  { name:'srs-fq-32768', type: 'string' },
  { name:'step-vk-invoices-commit', type: 'string' },
  { name:'step-vk-invoices-settleinvoice', type: 'string' },
  { name:'step-vk-invoices-createinvoice', type: 'string' },
  { name:'step-vk-invoices-init', type: 'string' },
  { name:'wrap-vk-invoices', type: 'string' },
  { name:'lagrange-basis-fp-1024', type: 'string' },
  { name:'lagrange-basis-fp-32768', type: 'string' },
  { name:'lagrange-basis-fp-65536', type: 'string' },
];
```

@here Thank you folks for all the help.
I was able to create a valid proof as well using this approach. And the `pk` are not taking much time to compile.. so the UX can be manageable.
Is Auro wallet still working? I'm not able to send transactions with it?
Great stuff @0xKriss1897!!
Thanks @gregor .. means a lot 🙂
hello, this step run in node only right, and web app only use file that have been generated ?
Yes. That is correct
thank for your solution, zkAPP is crazy
Happy to be of help @Quyen Lee
do you use zkappWorkerClient for each contract, or other way, can you share your project code
I only had one smart contract.. but I would suggest you to have one worker per smart contract
So that compiling happens in parallel, and same can be used in proof generation
I'm not sure if compiling in parallel helps a lot.. it's already using all available CPU threads for the heavier operations
By the way, how do you test and update CPU configuration in the o1js library? My M2 Max is not included in the configuration list in o1js for optimal performance

Jack originally tested the configs using cloud providers. However, they aren't kept up to date with new architectures and may not be comprehensive to begin with, Community input on these is very welcome. I don't even have a Macbook myself.

Can you share some test that needs to be run? I would be happy to test and provide test results to be included in the configuration; I think all the others will also be happy to receive optimal performance on their PCs.
Yup.. Silly me.. That does make sense.

@gregor @0xKriss1897 
Both SmartContract.compile() and Transaction.prove() are async functions but read and write functions of Cache.FileSystem are sync functions.
Getting prover keys from AWS S3 or CDN is impossible, as we need to call async functions for this.
Question: @gregor , is it possible to make read() and write() functions of Cache.FileSystem async?
Indeed. That is why I prefetched all the cache data apart from the prover keys, because of the large size.

And the prover keys were around 400-500mb per method, so it made sense to compile on the device itself.. 
But we can optimise to first compile the app without using prover keys, and then egarly fetch the prover keys.
+1 on this.. it will definately make the implementation a lot simpler
With async functions, you can download prover keys as needed from Netlify or AWS CDN. It will be pretty fast, so there is no need to download all the prover keys.
Exactly
And we can even utilise the Cache API to make things even more quicker
Interestingly, on AWS lambda compilation time of simple SmartContract decreased from 1 min 24 sec to 2.473 sec; it is 34 times!!! I have tested with all vk and pk in /tmp folder.

On my real, huge contract compilation on AWS lambda took:
```
INFO    compiled: 0.059ms
```
And loading 3 GB of prover files:
```
INFO    loaded nft cache: 2.698ms
```
The secret is that lambda reuses instances, and the cache was already loaded and contract compiled on this instance. Magic!
The first time, it was 50 sec for cache loading and 1 minute 40 seconds for compiling.
@gregor  I've created a new issue on github to make this solution official: https://github.com/o1-labs/o1js/issues/1251
Very cool @DFST! I don't get though what those "static data structures" are that you mention in the gh issue

I see from my tests that when I compile the contract and store the verification key in the static variable, on the next lambda run, if this static variable is set, I do not need to call compile(). It is how I achieved this massive reduction in compilation time.

AWS lambda on hot start keeps all the static variables and discards non-static variables. It is possible sometimes to rely on this behavior:
https://docs.aws.amazon.com/lambda/latest/dg/lambda-runtime-environment.html

What is essential for our case is that I can successfully prove and send transactions without calling compile() first, which means that the compilation results are stored in some static variables. The fact that my variable-keeping verification key still holds this key is enough to pass on to the compilation

I cannot say what exact static data structures are created during compilation. As I understand, it is happening inside the bindings code. 

To implement Proposal 1, we can rely on the verification key stored in a static variable, so the answer to your question in the context of Proposal 1 is simply the verification key.

Answer in the context of Proposal 2 - I don't know. I would need to explore the o1js code in much more detail than before to answer this.
Maybe those static variables: https://github.com/o1-labs/o1js/blob/main/src/lib/zkapp.ts#L611

embeds.title: o1js/src/lib/zkapp.ts at main · o1-labs/o1js
embeds.description: TypeScript framework for zk-SNARKs and zkApps. Contribute to o1-labs/o1js development by creating an account on GitHub.

messages.content: Thanks, I get it now!
The provers are represented by pickles as functions. I wonder if AWS can keep functions that have data like prover keys in their closures
https://github.com/o1-labs/o1js/blob/6e30ce74cf62260f964812172f7e60f64513ac69/src/lib/zkapp.ts#L622
The test shows that AWS keeps - otherwise, I would not be able to generate valid proof for the transaction
aaah now I really understand what you ask for in the gh issue. proposal 1 is very realistic, proposal 2 would need more work in the internals of pickles

I think if compile finds the prover functions already in place, that is sufficient to conclude that they don't have to be recreated? I.e., we do not care about the possiblity that the circuits changed (and a recompile is therefore necessary) _within the same JS process_? Because dynically changing circuits within a running JS process is an extremely exotic requirement
but does that change in an env like AWS?
should there be a quick check that the circuits didn't change? (can be done much quicker than compiling, by recomputing a circuit digest)

Yes, I fully agree. Now, even calling the contract with the wrong code is possible. Recently, I forgot to update the version of the imported minanft library in my code and have got a lot of weird errors as I was calling using the contract's old code, the contract with an already upgraded verification key.

So maybe we can handle it by checking the verification key of the deployed contract vs the static verification key of the SmartContract.
Maybe you can use the hash of _methods and _methodMetadata. There is already a digest() function, probably we can rely on it.
it's just not the quickest function. it runs the circuit, build a constraint system, and hashes that. can take a few seconds for large circuits
Then it is probably better to create a new one that hashes the contract metadata produced during TypeScript compilation
but that one doesn't tell us if the circuits changed o.O

Can we use a hash of some arguments of the compileProgram()? As far as I understand, compileProgram() is deterministic
https://github.com/o1-labs/o1js/blob/6e30ce74cf62260f964812172f7e60f64513ac69/src/lib/zkapp.ts#L685
It is deterministic but it's arguments are functions, and those can't easily be hashed
It is because of analyzeMethods()?
well analyzeMethods() is the essential part of it

Well, after all, we can add new argument to the compile(), like 
```typescript
forceRecompile : boolean = false
```
and let the zkApp developer decide if he wants to force recompilation. Maybe it is the easiest solution.
Love it!

I've made a proposal on zkIgnite Cohort 3 for this to make this caching into a E2E cache solution for zkApps. Please take some time to review the proposal. Your feedback will be very helpful in making it a better proposal.
https://zkignite.minaprotocol.com/zkignite/dev-tooling-infra-cohort-3_104/feedbackandrefinement/suggestion/738/detail

cc: @gordonfreeman @Quyen Lee @DFST

embeds.title: zkAppCache: A zk apps cache backed by edge network
embeds.description: Developers often encounter challenges when creating their first zkApp on Mina. One of the primary hurdles is the lengthy compilation time for zk apps on the browser and the complexity involved in setting up a cache in the browser. Through my efforts in caching, I successfully reduced compile times on the browser from approximately 10 minutes to ...

messages.content: header file are mandatory ?
Anyone has already deployed on vercel, my app load correctly in local but stuck on compilation on prod without any error, if I don't use cache it's working fine
Can you try `compile({ forceRecompile: true })` to see if there is any difference and check that your prover keys are actually loaded from CDN on prod
cache + force recompile ?
Yes. It will not resolve the issue, but will give more info for debugging
it's working
Ok, so check that the prover keys are actually loading in the frontend and are not corrupted, it looks like the problem with CDN.
I found the problem, some files missing, I use a script to generate the cache file, probably vercel skip some files or abort the script, now I push the files directly with the project
